document.docAuthor: Nunes, Rafael V. & Vaz-de-Mello, Fernando Z.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of Dichotomius (Cephagonus) Luederwaldt 1929 and the taxonomic status of remaining Dichotomius Hope 1838 subgenera (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae: Dichotomiini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic revision of Dichotomius (Cephagonus) Luederwaldt 1929 and the taxonomic status of remaining Dichotomius Hope 1838 subgenera (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae: Dichotomiini)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dichotomius ( selenocopris )
ascanius
ı
Vaz-de-Mello 2000
ı p. 193

Dichotomius ( selenocopris )
pauloensis
ı
Vaz-de-Mello 2000
ı p. 193

Diagnosis.
D. ascanius
is separated from the other two species of the group by the following combined characters: metasternum glabrous or with few setaeı sculpture between points visible (as in
D. mundus
); larger males bearing four lobes at anterior delimitation of pronotal disc (as in
D. bicuspis
); males ’ anterior declivity lacking coarse or ocellate punctures; metasternum glabrous or with few setae; males elytral striae deeply impressed and males ’ paramera dorsally bearing basal wide excavationı reaching the paramera sides.

● LECTOTYPE of
Pinotus ascanius
(maleı here designated): Brasilia.
P. ascanius
{white with red marginsı handwritten}/Museum Paris ex coll. Oberthur {greenı printed}/Ex. Museo Harold {white with black marginsı printed} [NMHN];

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription (larger males). Colour: blackı shiny. Head : fronto-clypeal surface smoothı lacking striations or punctures. Gena surface with very fine punctures. Gena borders slightly curved inwards. Inter-ocular space with fine punctures. Cephalic horn with acute round apex. Pronotum : pronotal disc shiny. Anterior portion of pronotal disc delimited by four lobes. Posterior margin with a single row of ocellateı unevenly spaced punctures. Metasternum : almost glabrousı margin of anterior lobe and sides with sparse scattered setae. Punctures getting larger towards external sides of the metasternum. Surface between punctures irregular. Elytra : striae deeply impressed with well-defined punctures. Punctures separated by 1ı5x their diameter. Interstriae convexı shiny and smoothı lacking microsculpture. Abdomen : sixth ventrite with strong basal groove all over its extension. Punctures present continuously along anterior margin of each ventrite. Aedeagus ( Figure 15 (d-f)): Paramera shortı having 1/third the length of phalobasisı dorsally having a wideı transversal basal excavationı reaching the sides of the parameraı longitudinal excavation lacking; apexes acuteı convergent. Laterallyı abrupt declivity towards the apex. Ventrallyı basis strongly sclerotised. Subgenital plate acute at base and widely emarginated at apex. Phalobaseı on lateral and ventral viewı widely excavated at apex.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 35.
D. blancoi
: (a) male dorsal habitus; (b) paramera dorsal view; (c) paramera ventral view; (d) paramera lateral view; (e) detail of the carena found on the middle of paramera longitudinal excavation.
D. candangoi
: (f) male dorsal habitus; (g) paramera dorsal view; (h) paramera ventral view; (i) paramera lateral view.

Figure 36. Distribution map of
D. ricardosilvaiı D. marcoscarvalhoiı D. furtadoiı D. barbaraeı D. tissianiaeı D. eması D. frizzasae
and D. candangoi .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Morphological variation. males BL: 9 – 15 mmı PW :
5 – 8 mm
. Smaller males lack horns and pronotal horns. Females BL: 10 – 13 mmı PW :
5 – 7 mm
. Distinguished from males as follows: Head: clypeo-genal angulation lacking in very small specimens; frontalı clypeal and genal surfaces transversely wrinkled. Cephalic carina very lowı producing a pair of weak tubercles. Pronotum: lacking lobes and anterior declivity. Abdomen/Pygidium: sixth ventrite widely emarginate mediallyı ‘ U ’ -shapedı emargination taking 1/5 of ventrite length ( Figure 8 (d)).
Distribution. Brazilian Atlantic Forests in the states of Bahiaı Espírito Santoı Paranáı Rio de Janeiro and Santa Catarina ( Figure 16 ).

Remarks. chosen Lectotype of
Pinotus ascanius
is the most developed male of the syntype series while Lectotype of
P. ascanius var. pygidialis
is the most conservated specimen of the syntype series.
Pinotus pauloensis
holotype has a malformation on the elytraı which makes it resembles D . ( L .) vidaurei Nunes and Vaz-de-Mello 2013 or
D. edmondsi
of
quadraticeps
group and described ahead in this work. Howeverı the male and female sixth ventrite and glabrous metasternum as well as its distribution are evidence to consider
D. pauloensis
a new synonym of
D. ascanius
.
